bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 29, 1941

div1.p: Kean makes a few suggestions on how to improve Truby's forward. He notes that he was on an inspection tour during Lazear's illness. He returned and thinks he saw Lazear the day before he died. He does not know when Reed heard of Lazear's death.

div1.p:
I am somewhat short of suitable paper myself
and will fall back on the T. J. memo - as it has besides
suitable envelopes for a real correspondence like
ours- My last letter of the 23rd had not arrived
when yours of the 26th came this morning. I had under
the agenda in my Scribble-In book to write to
you and return your preface- I have read it over
at different times and find that it is so perfectly
appropriate that I cannot improve it- I have
as you see made a few trifling suggestions to
reduce the number of times that the pronoun of the
first person naturally occurs in a preface, which
is addressed by the author to his readers- By
changing the active to passive we can duck a few
of these- Now to take up the questions in your letter
I really know any little of my own knowledge about
Lazear's illness because I was absent from Marianao
2-
Col. Havard and I had arranged for a tour of inspect-
ions and to escape the hot & dusty R. R. trip to Cienfuegos
we arranged to go there by sea on the transport Sedgwick
We accordingly went on her early in the morning of the
Sept. 19th I do not think that I knew there of Lazear's illness,
certainly not of the diagnosis- We made a slow trip
because we found an English Schooner in distress
off Cape San Antonio and had to low her all the way
into Cienfuegos- We returned to Havana also on the
Sedgwick and I did not home until the 24th Monday- When
I heard of Cartwrights death on the 23rd - Sunday and of the
grave illness of Lazear, who died the next day- Tuesday
I think I went to see him but he was so ill that I did
not stay- I have no record of this visit in my
diary however- Cartwright I had found sick at the Hd-
qrs just the Sunday before and had spent the day with him
& diagnosed his case as suspicious & sent him to the Y. F.
wards in the afternoon against his earnest protests.
I find in my diary “Tuesday Sept. 18. Field P. C. came in on the
Sedgwick last night. Baker, Truby and Ladd came also”

As to when Reed heard of Lazier's death I do not remem-
ber- If he did not sail from New York until Friday 28th
he doubtless heard it in Washington on the 27th- I am quite
confident that he knew it when we met him on the evening
of the 3rd of October but he may have heard it after he got to
Matansas but before we met him- Those transports with
good weather usually arrived in Cuba on the 5th day
which would fit in with sailing on the (28th)

list.item:
(2) Yes that fine old gentleman Dr. L. O. Howard is still alive
and is 87 years old so Adm. Still told us a week ago
as the meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Assn when we
elected him on the Board of Managers in place of Dr Stiles-
I think I wrote you this in my last letter- It will be
all right for you to quote anything he ever wrote me

(3) Now dont you waste your time on Major General
Walter Lawrence Reed for he is a quear dick-
There is no good reason that I can think of- for not answering your letter-
When he was made Inspector Gen. I called up
his mother on the phone and said. I want to congratulate
you on Lawrence's fine promotion. I will not send
him any congratulation because he never answers my
letters "- She said “Oh you must not mind that, he
never answers mine either”-

(4.) I wrote you in my last of having received your
memoir from Dr. Hench- I have not read our Pinto's
remarks carefully but will do so tomorrow-
I will pass it on to Elizabeth shortly.
I have been much interrupted since I began
this by visitors and will now stop and get a
much needed dose of medicine for my cold-
I'll give you one guess as to what it will be-
I wrote you how pleased I was with Andrus's
Tale of a Guinea Pig- Love to the dear lady
